Make our nation safe again.
Our God-given Common Sense.
And now, Rudy Giuliani with Common Sense.
Hello, this is Rudy Giuliani and welcome to Rudy's Common Sense.

can call it a war.
Of course, it's a, hopefully it's a peaceful war, but a war between the parents and the

So the parents and the activists really, with the school boards either being captured or
not being captured by the left wing activists and it turns on the education of their children.
Education on the traditional subjects, which by every measure, when you compare us to

And then the traditional subjects that have been removed and the new subjects that now

And then sex and gender identification education, which I think most parents didn't even realize

A lot of this came about because of the pandemic with people, people at home, children getting

if I had children of that age, or parents, or children just coming home and telling them

Teacher said white people are all racist.

So many different things encompassed in this.

There are no federal laws here.

And we have with us John Saylor, who has over this summer and before written very, very

articles that are well balanced and most importantly articles that are accessible.
And I thought it would be useful for all of us who are going to be facing this issue for

So John, how are you?
Doing great.
Thanks.
How are you?
Good.
Welcome.
Welcome to Rudy's Common Center.
Great pleasure to have you here.
And the articles, the articles that the articles that I mentioned will get to in a moment.

I saw the press release on June 1st of 2021.
Tell us your background before that.
And then we'll get to that.
So I am a former teacher.
I've taught at charter schools, Christian schools from everywhere between Harlem and

So I have a background working in K through 12 education.
But I'm also very interested in public policy, which is why I eventually signed on to become
a research associate here at the National Association of Scholars, which is why you find

So now what motivated you, I mean, there's so much you could, your, your, your, a belly

How did you come to focus on the current issues about, let's call it controversial educational

Well, I think it's one of the key issues of our day.
And I think it's that way because there are a lot of organizations, a lot of people

be able to disagree with.
And I find those, many of those views to be damaging, damaging to children and to our

Well, how long has this been going on without our as a society really knowing it?
Or let's say it was confined to a very small group of people because it seems to have broken
out now to the whole of society.
But this has been going on for some time.
I'm almost going to say below the surface.
Yeah, I would say that there are sort of two waves of this movement.
On one hand, a lot of it arose from the universities becoming more and more ideologically charged,
which of course is a big focus of the National Association of Scholars.
And as the universities have become more ideologically charged, education schools in particular
have trained teachers and people with really sterling credentials to think in this way,
to treat these wild ideas about gender or about racializing ideologies as unquestionably
true.
And so you start seeing organizations like gender spectrum come into being and become

the ideology that informs the new movement toward, for instance, activist civics, that's
been going on for a lot longer than that.
These ideologies, for instance, critical race theory can be traced back to the 1980s and
I would say that that was the first wave where it was happening sort of under the radar,
but a significant amount of change.
It was really hard to overstate this occurred in the summer of 2020.
So the reason I know so much about this organization, gender spectrum is because I've done a lot
of research on private schools and the way that the top private schools in the country,
the ones that you've probably heard of, have all issued massive institutional changes that
touch every part of the curriculum to change the their institutions to fulfill, to carry
out diversity, equity and inclusion goals.
And not only, I discovered that it's not just private schools doing this, it's not just
private schools totally overhauling their institutions, it's school boards.
Well, you know, it's a bunch of stuff.

It's interesting because I think most people, until your articles and a few things that

problem.

And schools were an issue then because of lack of performance because of comparisons where
we were slipping to third and fourth and fifth and sixth.
Now we're somewhere in the twenties or thirties with math, English, the basic subjects.
And parents, aware parents were very upset about it.

So those debates go back some time.

Has this agenda been introduced in the public schools before it was introduced in the private

I think that both kinds of institutions have sort of followed the same timeline.
So you start to see them taking a much more explicit stand for these kinds of things,
especially in 2020, but really it's been happening for a couple of years.
So you see private schools using gender spectrum, the organization that I've wrote about for

But you also see public schools doing that.

Their mission, the mission of gender spectrum is to teach children that gender is non-binary

country and primarily public schools.

Maybe not all of them in every single school district or private school.
That sort of the basic, it seems to me it's in part race, in part history, which also

And then we have gender and sex education.
And they seem to be part of the same package.

Who's doing this?

If you want us to sink definition of what it is they're going for, some people call it

Some people call it critical race theory or critical theory in general.

One person calls it the successor ideology, the ideology that comes after liberalism.
That means that everything from gender to even civics education is looked at through

race, class, gender, sexual orientation.
So what we're seeing is an outsized focus on these things.
Of course, nobody wants to ignore America's history with race.
But that's not what these people are really proposing, just look at America's history

Rather, they're proposing that we look at virtually everything through the lens not only a race

or oppressors.
And that's what I think is really pernicious about all of this.
So there are groups, a number of them like gender spectrum that are quite involved in
programs like this.
But is gender spectrum one of the larger and one of the bigger ones?
Gender spectrum is unique because they're the primary organization pushing for what
I call gender ideology.
So they go into schools and they tell fifth grade teachers to teach their fifth grade
classes that gender is non-binary.
And then tell their students to chart themselves on three different gender spectrum charts,
sex, gender expression, gender identity.
This is deeply confusing material.
And so they are by far the largest organization that does this in schools.
So you describe in your article something I think that's very graphic and very useful
for people to understand this.

on the white board three circles.

Ibram X can be basic.
His basic philosophy is simple.
He says that any difference, any difference at all in outcomes for different groups is just automatically racism.

And once you accept certain premises about what they call intersectionality or about identity, then all of these issues blend together.

There is a direct lineage and there are also a lot of people who find that kind of speak to be persuasive.
